article.title: Molecular Mechanism of Transition from Catch-Bond to Slip-Bond in Fibrin

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between tensile force and average bond lifetime as shown in the graph for fibrin-fibrinogen (Fn:Fg) interactions?
choices: Average bond lifetime increases linearly with increasing tensile force.
Average bond lifetime decreases linearly with increasing tensile force.
Average bond lifetime initially increases with tensile force, peaks around 30-35 pN, and then decreases.
Average bond lifetime remains constant regardless of changes in tensile force.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the average bond lifetime (τ) of fibrinogen fragment D interacting with various fibrin fragments under different tensile forces (f). Which interaction exhibits the strongest catch-bond behavior?
choices: D:E
D:desA-E
D:desAB-E
All interactions show equally strong catch-bond behavior.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure illustrates two different pathways of A:a knob-hole bond dissociation. What is the key molecular event distinguishing the low-affinity (Pathway 1) from the high-affinity (Pathway 2) bound state?
choices: The complete dissociation of the knob \'a\' from the hole \'a\'.
The translocation and interaction of the movable flap with the knob \'a\'.
The initial number of binding contacts (Q) at the start of the dissociation.
The shape of the unbinding force (F) curve over time.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure depicts a model for forced dissociation of the A:a knob-hole bond. What does the fluctuating bottleneck represent in this model?
choices: The knob \'a\' itself.
The entire γ-nodule.
The binding interface (hole \'a\').
The tensile force applied to the complex.

multiple_choice_question.text: This table shows model parameters for the A:a knob-hole bottleneck. What parameter exhibits the most significant difference between the continuous and discrete versions of the model?
choices: Interface stiffness (κ)
Initial interface width (x<sub>0</sub>)
Escape rate constant (k<sub>0</sub>)
Transition distance for dissociation (σ<sub>y</sub>)
